answer_html:
For our case, we have
\(A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3\\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
and \(\textrm{Det}(A)=1\). Therefore,
\(A^{-1}= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3\\ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
is the inverse of the matrix.

hints_html: What is the formula for a 2x2 matrix inverse involving its determinant?

question: A 05
sols_html:
For any \(2\times{2}\) matrix,
\(A= \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\)
we can write the inverse as,
\(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{\textrm{Det}(A)}\begin{bmatrix} d & -b\\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}\)
with \(\textrm{Det}(A)=ad-bc\). For our case, we have
\(A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3\\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
and \(\textrm{Det}(A)=2(2)-3(1)=1\). Therefore,
\(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{1}\begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3\\ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3\\ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
is the inverse of the matrix.
